Navigation
Name Test/Libraries/List/toMapUnique
Synopsis Convert a list of tuples to a map; result must be a map.
Function map[&A,&B] toMapUnique(list[tuple[&A, &B]] lst) throws DuplicateKey
Usage import List;
Description Convert a list of tuples to a map; result must be a map.
Examples 
rascal>import List;
ok
rascal>toMapUnique([<1,10>, <2, 20>, <3, 30>]);
map[int, int]: (3:30,2:20,1:10)
Let's explore an error case: 
rascal>toMapUnique([<1,10>, <1, 11>, <2, 20>, <3, 30>]);
exception:MultipleKey(1)
stacktrace:|stdin:///|(0,48,<1,0>,<1,48>)
	somewhere in: public org.eclipse.imp.pdb.facts.IValue org.rascalmpl.library.Prelude.toMapUnique(org.eclipse.imp.pdb.facts.IList)
	somewhere in: ___SCREEN_INSTANCE___44
Pitfalls The keys in a map are unique by definition. toMapUnique throws a MultipleKey exception when the list contains more than one tuple with the same first value.
[Edit] | [New Subconcept] | [Recompile Course] | [Warnings]
